an8.13:1.1: “Mendicants, a fine royal thoroughbred with eight factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and considered a factor of kingship.
an8.13:1.3: It’s when a fine royal thoroughbred is well born on both
an8.13:1.4: the mother’s and the father’s sides.
an8.13:1.5: He’s bred in the region fine thoroughbreds come from.
an8.13:1.8: he eats carefully, without making a mess.
an8.13:1.9: He’s disgusted by sitting or lying down in excrement or urine.
an8.13:1.10: He’s sweet-natured and pleasant to live with, and he doesn’t upset the other horses.
an8.13:1.11: He openly shows his tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints to his trainer,
an8.13:1.12: so the trainer can try to subdue them.
an8.13:1.14: ‘Whether or not the other horses carry their loads, I’ll carry mine.’
an8.13:1.15: He always walks in a straight path.
an8.13:1.16: He’s strong, and stays strong even until death.
an8.13:1.17: A fine royal thoroughbred with these eight factors is worthy of a king. …
an8.13:2.1: In the same way, a mendicant with eight factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
an8.13:2.3: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an8.13:2.7: They're disgusted with bad conduct by way of body, speech, or mind,
an8.13:2.8: and by attainment of the many kinds of unskillful things.
an8.13:2.9: They're sweet-natured and pleasant to live with, and they doesn’t upset the other mendicants.
an8.13:2.10: They openly show their tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints to their sensible spiritual companions,
an8.13:2.11: so they can try to subdue them.
an8.13:2.13: ‘Whether or not the other mendicants do their training, I’ll do mine.’
an8.13:2.14: They always walk in a straight path.
an8.13:2.15: And here the straight path is
an8.13:2.16: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
an8.13:2.18: ‘Gladly, let my skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the blood and flesh waste away in my body! I will not stop trying until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.’
an8.13:2.19: A mendicant with these eight factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”
